Time stamp 2:39

Airplane on treadmill: Airplane will take off as normal. The treadmill has no effect on the movement of the airplane. Think about it this way. You're running on a treadmill. You have a rope attached to you. Attached to the other end of the rope is your friend. Your friend pulls on the rope. It doesn't matter HOW fast you run on the treadmill, you're going to get pulled off of the treadmill. Why? Because the treadmill has no effect on your friend pulling you with the rope. It is literally a force from outside the system. In the airplane scenario, the propeller is the rope. You LITERALLY cannot pull the treadmill fast enough to even ATTEMPT to "keep up" with the plane. The only, and I mean ONLY want the treadmill could affect the plane is if it were being pulled fast enough so that the friction in the wheels of the plane were counteracting the force of the propeller. And considering that... well... the entire point of the propeller is to generate force, and the entire point of the wheels is to NOT have friction. Yeah, that's impossible.

its got nothing to do with the compressibility of the water. the air gives the water room to MOVE. the movement creates a current that does the mixing. without air and a vertical movement there was no current created in the water therefore no mixing. spining the bottle or shaking in more than 1 axis creates a current in the water that mixes the blue water with the clear. by spining the bottle friction and inertia create a current in the water that causes the mixing.

The reason it is mixing when spun is because you are giving it an angular motion rather than a linear motion. When you just shake it up and down all of the water is moving at the same speed in the same direction, which is preventing it from mixing. On the other hand when spun the water further out from the axis of rotation is moving faster than the water closer to the center. Also I believe the ridges on the bottom are what is causing water to kind of shoot upwards after the spin, because as the water on the bottom tries to rotate around the center it hits the ridge and then is redirected upward.

I do not believe I will explain it well but I will give it a shot. If you have something turning circularly (like a circle shaped piece of wood attached to a drill perhaps) and attach a rod to one end of the circle that can spin freely and attach the other end of the rod to something on a track (plate A)  that can only travel in one dimension the drill should be able to lift and lower Plate A as the circle spins. the attached rod will lower plate A when it is at the bottom of the circle and will raise plate A when it is at the top.
